Award.AwardTitle: Comparative Phylogeography of Central African Duikers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the historical and ecological processes underlying high species diversity in the tropics has been the subject of intense interest and led to the formulation of many diversity hypotheses. In particular, the role of tropical forest "refuges", river barriers and ecological gradients in promoting speciation has been the subject of much recent debate. This study will use a molecular approach to test for these potential mechanisms of diversification by comparing spatial patterns of genetic variation in a suite of forest antelope species. Data from this study will then be used to test predicted patterns of genetic variation associated with these different diversification modes and examine their relative importance. In order to achieve the intense geographical sampling required for this study, this project will use dung from natural populations as a source of DNA.

The implementation of such a project relies heavily on the participation of collaborating host institutions comprising the Centre International de Recherches Medicales in Franceville, Gabon (CIRMF), the Universite des Sciences et Techniques de Masuku in Gabon (USTM) and the Gabon Program of the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS), a conservation NGO based in New York. Through this collaboration, this project will stimulate exchange of expertise between African and U.S. participants and provide opportunities for technology transfer between countries. This study will not only provide important information on the potential mechanisms of diversification in the Afro-tropics but will also provide a molecular inventory of species distributions and solid genetic database for informing long-term conservation management of central African forest antelope. This award was co-funded by both EPSCoR and the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Discovering the factors that may be responsible for the astonishingly high biodiversity in tropical rainforests has intrigued biologists for more than a century. Numerous hypotheses have been proposed to explain how this diversity arose but of these three have attracted considerable attention. The first one argues that during the ice ages, the climate became colder and drier in the tropics and many forests retracted into isolated pockets or refugia.  Forest species tied to these refugia were also isolated and subsequently developed genetic differences from populations in other refugia. Another hypothesis argues that major tropical rivers may have separated populations from one another and driven genetic differences between them. Lastly, a third hypothesis argues that transitions between forests and their adjacent savannas may have also driven genetic differences between populations.

 

Although it is generally difficult to study mammals in their natural habitats, molecular technologies are now available to obtain genetic data from geo-referenced feces using a “non-invasive” approach. The main aim of this project was therefore to use non-invasive sampling to test these three hypotheses of tropical diversification in forest duiker antelope. Forest duikers are an excellent model for testing hypotheses of tropical forest diversification owing to the large number of species within this group, their relatively high abundance in African tropical forests and the ease with which they can be sampled using a non-invasive sampling strategy. However most, if not all, forest duikers are impossible to discriminate on the basis of the physical appearance of their feces, necessitating the development of a molecular diagnostic capable of identifying species from their DNA.

 

The first step of this project was to find the best way to store feces in the field until they could be brought into the lab for DNA extraction. By doing this, we were able to provide concrete guidelines for other researchers interested in carrying out non-invasive genetic studies on forest antelope. The next step was to develop a molecular tool that could be used to identify duiker fecal samples to species level. To do this, we collected a large dataset of already identified samples from duikers and other closely related forest hoofed animals. By comparing the unknown DNA samples to reference DNA samples of known species origin, we could then determine the fecal samples to species level. The molecular diagnostic we have developed has numerous applications in species management and conservation. These applications include mapping species distributions and their habitat associations and as a forensic tool to potentially help regulate trade in wild meat. This work was also extended to an analysis of the systematics of this group and revealed that some species are not genetically differentiated from one another, calling into question the number of species currently recognized within this group and their relationships to one another.  We also developed numerous genetic resources for analyzing fine-scale population differences in duikers and other closely related animals that will provide opportunities for other researchers interested in the ecology, population biology and evolutionary history of this group. We have also found that duiker populations from one species do not appear to be structured by a major river within Gabon.
